title: Mum-of-two lost nearly all the blood in her body after giving birth - but miraculously survived
text:
Heather Armstrong and her daughter Ava (Photo: Plymouth Herald/SWNS) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A young mother has hailed her survival as miraculous after she lost nearly all of the blood in her body after giving birth . 
Heather Armstrong haemorrhaged a massive amount of blood following the delivery of her daughter Ava last December. 
Doctors removed the 24-year-old's placenta manually and found that her uterus was collapsing, but by then she had lost two litres of blood. 
Heather eventually lost nearly four litres of blood during the emergency - with the average adult having 4.7-5.5 litres in their body - and credits hospital staff with saving her life. Heather says she has only just got back to feeling normal again (Photo: Plymouth Herald/SWNS) 
The young mother was rushed to theatre for an emergency operation where a balloon was inflated and her womb packed to stem the blood. Read More 
She was given 10 units of blood - four litres - to replace what she'd lost and survived the near-death experience at Derriford Hospital, Plymouth. 
Heather, of Whitleigh, Plymouth, has since returned home to baby Ava, now three months, and partner Kieron. 
She said: "I haemorrhaged pretty bad, losing almost four litres of blood - which is around the amount in your whole body. (Photo: Plymouth Herald/SWNS) 
"I was on the high dependency unit for five days as my iron levels were not staying high enough and I was at risk of cardiac arrest. 
"Kieron looked after the baby - I didn't get a chance to care for her - the midwives and nurses were great with Ava. 
"I was given 10 units of blood, which equated to four litres." 
The mum-of-two has been in and out of hospital since for iron transfusions and blood tests. 
She said she has only just got back to feeling like herself again after a long and painful recovery after Ava was born - initially without any complications - on December 12. 
Heather added that fortunately, Ava was overdue and needed to be induced in hospital. Read More Pensioner dies in agony of stomach cancer after swabs confirmed illness but doctors sent him home with paracetamol 
The couple had originally planned a home birth, so if that had happened it's likely Heather would not have made it to the hospital in time to get the blood she needed. 
The part-time nail technician added: "We previously had a meeting with the midwife to discuss a home birth - we had really considered it, but if we had had one I wouldn't be here today. 
"The care at Derriford was amazing, I couldn't fault it. 
"I had one-to-one care throughout - without the amazing staff and the generosity of people donating blood, I without a doubt wouldn't be here today." Like us on Facebook
